comment: Not good at all. Tastes bad, almost like there is tequila mixed in.

I bought a bottle of this because I was told it was what my grandpa drank, and thought it would be a nice way to connect with the man I never knew.  It worked as I now know that my grandpa had poor taste in scotch; a fact previously unknown to me.
Light smoke. Not super smooth but enjoyable
Fairly smooth. Not as harsh as typical whisky. Best with a few drops of water.
On the same lines as Johnnie Walker Red label. Not very good.

Citrus and honey with some briny quality on the nose.  Cereal and sweetness arrive as it opens.  Creamy and full on the palate.  Slight honey sweetness fades quick. Mild tongue burn on the tip and sides.  Black pepper-spicy, bitter finish.  With water/ice the sweetness is more pronounced and the spicy finish is weakened. Definitely a dram to serve over ice.  Not complex. Better than I expected.
First brand of scotch to ever try and first impression it is very flavorful. Definite citrus taste almost lemony. Aftertaste bit strong on borderline tart. Great for the price.
Not bad. Kind of a grainy aroma and aftertaste. Better for mixing than neat.
A classic example of getting what you pay for, cutty sark delivers a cheap scotch that at best may be described as "not bad"
A nice even whiskey for mixing.
Very easy to drink, not much depth of flavor. Definitely fruity.

Super uneventful by itself. Mostly grain whisky. I use it as a base to blend in better more complex whiskys. It is nondescript enough to take on the flavor of your favorite single malt. Splash of water opens it up.
Worst Scotch I have ever tasted

Actually have no complaints.  Very light and simple.  Fresh.  Very easy to sip, and would be a great introduction without scaring someone off.  I won't reach for it often, but wouldn't be afraid of it either if that's what they had at the pub.

Cutty Sark, a no age ststement blended scotch whisky from The Erdington Group. Price $20.00, Sampled 1/13/16 with 1 teaspoon of water in a Glencairn spirits nosing glass.

Aroma - Soured grain, corn, rough ethanol, movie butter, yellow cake and lime leaf.

Taste - Light peach and apricot, malt, cereal, very thin and easy to down.

Finishes very quickly overall. 

Final score : 2 / 5, for a 20 dollar bottle of scotch this is....ok... you could do slightly better for 20, but not a whole lot worse at the same time. This whisky is good for drinking long or as a mixer, but isn't worth slow sipping. For the price you'd might as get grab yourself a bottle of Speyburn 10 and have an infinitely better experience. Glad to have tried, don't feel too bad for the price I paid but, will not be buying another bottle.

Don't bother looking for recognizable flavors of The Macallan or Highland Park in this blend (two of the component single malts) because you won't find them.  What you will find is a nice interplay between vanilla and citrus on the nose and palate.  The finish is a little bitter but that's to be expected from a budget blend.  Cutty Sark's lightness makes it ideal for mixing and it works good over ice on a hot day.

Little sharp around the edges due to youth and grain, but turns into a very smooth and creamy mouth feel. Tastes fruity and cereal, like a jammy biscuit. Goes down very smooth with a finish that doesn't linger. Overall its good for the $20 price point!

While nothing special, for the price it is a pleasant enough whiskey to drink. I find that the fruit quality is enhanced with a slight chill, but it is already a light whiskey. So, drink with a few chilled whiskey stones and it is pretty enjoyable, especially for the low price.

Floral with some cereal notes coming through under the nose. Light bodied, with some malt and faint notes of citrus  on the palate, but otherwise devoid of much flavour. The finish is short and slightly oaky. There is certainly not much to brag about here, but for $25 CAD a bottle, there is also not much to complain about either.
I’ve never had anything like it, and it’s great. Sweet is dominated by a tart burn and it really is “oily” whatever that is. I’d have it again and prefer it to fruity highlands.
Seems tasty. Mild and traditional scotch flavor. Not spicy or smoky.

Whisky number 3 from my recent purchase of 12 affordable blends. This is the first time I've ever tasted Cutty Sark.

Nose:  Fruity sweet with some cereal and honey notes. It's light and fresh but there is a fullness to it as well - it's certainly not a dry spirit. I'd risk a guess that the oak used for this still had a spark of life left as it's not overly bitter or tannic, at least in comparison to some blends at this price point.

Palate: Also lightly sweet but not as fruity as the nose - more like barley sugar with a creamy cereal quality and a slight oilyness. It's a nice mouthfeel, particularly for a lower-priced blend. There's a nutty hint and even a little caramel, but it's not heavy.

Finish: Cereal flavours and a slight sweet hot spice, but it is very short.

On the whole it's pleasant and compared with other blends in the price range is reasonable value. It is a good mixer with dilution bringing out even more sweetness and even the faintest smoky flavour. It makes a very nice highball but is easily overpowered by cola or dry ginger.

The profile reminded me a little of Ballantine's Finest but Cutty Sark has a sweeter finish, particularly when diluted, and a bit less body. The dry glass has an unusual floral-charcoal aroma, but it is very light.

"Acceptable" : 2 stars.
Ellekari likes this one, easy to drink, whiskey for beginners. Cool with a boat on it :)

It's lightness is apparent in the glass. Light straw color with an equally light nose of sweet cereal. The sweet grain continues on the palate with almost non-existent char. A light blend for easy sipping.

Cutty Sark has a very pale , champagne appearance, with strong alcohol legs, however. The aroma is of a quite low profile earthy, smoky peat. Taste is similarly mellow. Some might call it bland, but I think it must take extreme skill to blend these light ones, without presenting any off or off-kilter notes. Mouthfeel is light, and finish is relatively quick. RJT
Trash. Only whiskey I couldn’t finish the glass with. Gave the bottle away.
Great for sipping and mixing. Light and refreshing.

향 : 물기젖은 수건, 눅눅한, 녹슨, 쇠
맛 : 달콤한 쇠구슬, 가벼운, 다른곡물
피니쉬 : 짧은 스파이시, 약간의 플로랄, 쇠구슬, 걸레, 눅눅한 피트,

Saw this featured in “Green Book” (albeit less than favorably) and thought I would give it a try.

Nose: mildew, orange rind, vanilla.
Palate: watery, citrus.
Finish: medium length, a little spicy.
Water greatly improves the nose by removing the stink of the mildew, but dulls the palate considerably.
Overall: it tastes better than it smells, not entirely unpleasant, but fairly bland.
I don't love this on it's own.  I prefer to use it for making a hot toddy.  And after reading the description it seems like I chose well.
I prefer to use this for a top shelf hot toddy.  I use fresh ginger tea with lemon and honey.

The most friendly whiskey I ever had. Not harsh on the throat, for the price it’s a gem. Light color charcole smokiness lightly blended with honey and pear notes. Mixable and straight worthy, must have on a everyday bar stoke.

I know this isn't going to sound like a typical review, but it smelled rank when I opened the bottle. It tasted sour. I tried it with a generous amount of ginger ale; didn't help. So, I'm supposed to try it with soda, see if I like it? In the cupboard it goes.

*Free in the United Club @ Denver Airport*
Nose- lemony, herbal & cereal
Palate- slightly oily with return notes of herb and lemon but also a hint of smoke
Finish- gone quick
*Free/would not repeat*
Light, thin and enjoyably sippable. Comforting like an afternoon tea with lemon and honey, with some herbs and just a shade of smoke.
Honey, lemon and herbs on the nose, light, oily honey on the palate, warm short finish.
I've drank this brand for a number of years.. It's a classic. 😉🥃
This shouldn’t exist. Tastes like watered scotch

Appearance: A light straw color is the hue in this high selling blended scotch. Very thin, semi-viscous legs slide down the inside of the glass after a swirl.

Nose: On the nose I find notes of grain, dusty corn, a small touch of peat, some ashy smoke, salted caramel candy, and a light lemon flourish. 

Taste: The palate I find, as their website suggests, not harsh at all. There are notes of honey, some light peat again, lemon or clementine citrus, and red grape. Simple and inoffensive.

Finish: The short finish leaves a lemony note that has rung true through the majority of the experience. 

Thoughts: This blended scotch was a decent dram: affordable, decent tasting, and has a cool history. It’s not a hero whiskey one needs to explore very hard; on the Cutty Sark website they even suggest its best utilized when mixed. I’ll probably not buy it again, but won’t turn anyone away from trying it if they haven’t already. Thanks Cutty Sark! I’m curious to try your Prohibition Edition. Sláinte!
思ったより美味しくない。ピート感はゼロ。これはスコッチではない（独断）
飲みやすくて個人的に好きな味
Very simple but fruity and easy to drink. I enjoyed it neat and you can not say that about many drams at this price point.
A solid budget blend that’s worth every penny.  Neat, on ice, in a scotch n soda...you can’t go wrong.
Just fine if you’re low on money. Best served on ice as it’s pretty rough when neat.

Rund og god! Enebær-aktig? Minner om cognac og genever men kan være bare meg
«Born to mix» sier hjemmesiden
Fra Papy’s leilighet
There is a sweetness in here that I am not a fan of - almost cotton candy?? Anyone else? I will try again soon
Light flavour, medium to high body, grain alcohol, lightly dry finish

Simple and soft, it is not a bad dram at all. Just simple.

Bottled at 40%abv, with a pale staw color.

On the nose is very dim, with notes of stinky peat, tobacco, pepper, salt, sea aroma, vanilla and chocolate lindt.

On the palate is normal but fine, with caramel, liquorice, pepper, tobacco, and the finish is sweet & salty, with a mild hotness, and chocolate lindt.

Overall this one is a 75 over 100.

After hearing good things about this blend I decided to give it a try. It’s a cheap blend from Edrington Group (even though they sold it recently I think this bottle is still from that era), but so is Famous Grouse and I really enjoyed that one, so why not drop the $20 and give it a go?  Bottled at 40% ABV and chill filtered, but is a natural color of pale straw. 

The nose is intensely sweet up front. It’s almost completely dominated by ripe green pears, very sugary sweet. Also some white grape/peach juice and a very light coconut and pineapple. A floral note, perhaps apple blossoms. Salty, slightly biscuity with a very light lemon and honey. Ashy and wood smoke, but not your typical peaty profile. 

The palate is intense for 40%, but most of that is a young peppery grain harshness. More of those ripe pears...piles of them. Peach, apricot, salty and sour. Not much after that. 

Light to medium bodied, thin but creamy, mouthwatering. 
The finish is short with grain alcohol, pears and salt. 

I have to admit, I had a hard time trying to pull nosing notes out of this one. The pears were so dominant for me that I missed a lot. I had to check other reviews to get my bearings. The palate was a little more straightforward. Either way, this is not a whisky for sipping neat. It does, however, get masked by cola very well. I mixed Pepsi with this (about 3:1 pop to whisky) and there was hardly any alcoholic presence. For the money, which is forgivably low, I’d rather buy a bottle of Famous Grouse. At least with that you get a hint of Macallan and Highland Park. Will not buy again unless it’s to be specifically used as a mixer. 
Cheers
Very rough, best mixed, powerful afterbite

An incredible value, and a terrific gateway Scotch for the squeamish. Deceptively smooth. I'll be keeping this on my shelf. 

Neat: Saltwater taffy, brine that is somehow reminiscent of soy sauce. Metallic astringency. Some definite buttered popcorn business happening. 

With a droplet: the salt remains, but the peat becomes more mossy and boggy. The toffee and sugary malts bloom. The burn wafts away.

Heavy salt comes first, followed by honey and a hint of peat. Briny sea salt. Mild corn grits. Stays on the lips in a nice way. Minor but pleasant burn at the end. It's very warming on the lips. The salt is a flavor I have just started to pick up on so I may be predisposed to identifying it. It's very pleasant neat.
